definition[0]: to make food that you are preparing flat and thin by pushing a rolling pin over it
example[0]: Roll out the dough on a floured surface.
definition[1]: to make a new product available for people to buy or use
example[1]: The company expects to roll out the new software in September.
definition[2]: to leave a place, especially later than expected
example[2]: We used to hear people rolling out of the pubs at closing time.
example[3]: He finally rolled out of bed at noon.
definition[3]: to put something flat on the ground or a surface, when it was previously rolled into a tube shape
example[4]: We rolled out our sleeping bags under the stars.
definition[4]: to make special preparations for an important visitor
definition[5]: an occasion when a new product is made available for people to buy or use
example[5]: Sun had to cancel the intended roll-out of the 514 model.
definition[6]: to supply a new product to shops and companies in a region or country after it has been successfully tested and marketed in a small area
example[6]: The company expects to roll several new products soon.
